newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey sees need for security cordon in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Turkey sees need for security cordon in Iraq.

text.p: Turkish Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller said on Friday renewed upheaval in northern Iraq made necessary Turkey's planned creation of a security zone there.
She said the cordon would deter infiltration by guerrillas of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), which is fighting to establish self-rule in Turkey's mainly Kurdish southeast.
Interviewed by BBC World Television, Ciller called the zone a "must".
But echoing other officials who spelled out limited Turkish military goals, Ciller insisted: "It is going to be temporary kind of activity".

President Suleyman Demirel late on Friday called a security summit on northern Iraq, meeting with the chief of staff and the head of intelligence as well as Ciller and the interior and defence ministers.

Iraq has already expressed its displeasure with Ankara's military build-up at the border with Kurdish-held northern Iraq. At midnight on Thursday, Iraq summoned a senior Turkish diplomat in Baghdad to complain about the concentration of force.
But despite a surge of Turkish troop movements and air patrols near the border on Thursday, Ankara and U.N. officials said the Turkish army had yet to make a move.
"There is nothing happening," Ahmet Erturk, deputy governor of Turkey's southeastern provinces, told reporters.

After clashes flared this week in northern Iraq between two Iraqi Kurdish factions, Ankara revived the long-standing idea of a security zone to repel the PKK, which uses the Iraqi terrain as a springboard for its attacks on Turkey.
More than 20,000 people have died in 12 years of fighting between the rebels and the Turkish army.
The governor's office for Turkey's southeastern provinces under emergency rule said on Friday that Turkish troops killed 26 PKK rebels in clashes in the area.
The promise of only a temporary security cordon is key to securing the support of Washington, Turkey's closest ally.
"We're not raising any particular objections based on what the Turks have told us," State Department spokesman Glyn Davies told a news briefing on Thursday.

The United States, leading an anti-Iraqi alliance, fired two volleys of cruise missiles at southern Iraqi military targets this week in retaliation for Iraqi intervention in the Kurdish fighting last week.
But France on Friday came out against a buffer zone, saying the international community had reaffirmed its commitment to Iraq's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

"We have security problems at our borders," Ciller said. "Each time this kind of military action happens, the terrorists build up on our borders and then try to infiltrate. So we need this security zone there."
Foreign ministry officials said "conditions" would determine how long the cordon would remain and how many troops would patrol the zone, set to extend up to 10 km (six miles) deep into northern Iraq.

In Baghdad, Iraqi Foreign Minister Saeed al-Sahaf summoned the Turkish acting charge d'affaires to complain the Turkish military measures "constituted a totally unjustified conduct and a violation of Iraq's sovereignty," Baghdad newspapers said.

On Friday Ciller hosted consultations with Deputy Chief of Staff General Cevik Bir, the defence and interior ministers, Under-Secretary of the Foreign Ministry Onur Oymen and the secretary of the Turkish secret service.
